image.altText: A composite image of Ben Carroll and Jacinta Allan.

props.synopsis: Deputy Premier Jacinta Allan may be facing a challenge from Public Transport Minister Ben Carroll in her bid to replace Daniel Andrews after his shock resignation on Tuesday.  Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Showdown looms for Victoria's top job as Labor MPs meet

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Since yesterday, Jacinta Allan has been the frontrunner to replace Daniel Andrews. But this just in from state political reporter Bridget Rollason: We're hearing Deputy Premier Jacinta Allan could face a challenge for the Labor party leadership. Labor MPs have told the ABC Public Transport Minister Ben Carroll could put his hat in the ring for the top job, meaning it might be a showdown between Ms Allan and Mr Carroll. The caucus meeting to choose the new leader is set to get underway shortly — ministers are waiting for outgoing premier Daniel Andrews to arrive.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Signs it may not be 'smooth sailing' for Jacinta Allan

children.content: Since yesterday, Jacinta Allan has been the frontrunner to replace Daniel Andrews.
But this just in from state political reporter Bridget Rollason:
We're hearing Deputy Premier Jacinta Allan could face a challenge for the Labor party leadership.
Labor MPs have told the ABC Public Transport Minister Ben Carroll could put his hat in the ring for the top job, meaning it might be a showdown between Ms Allan and Mr Carroll.
The caucus meeting to choose the new leader is set to get underway shortly — ministers are waiting for outgoing premier Daniel Andrews to arrive.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This just in from state political reporter Bridget Rollason: It's looking like Treasurer Tim Pallas could be Victoria's next Deputy Labor Leader. Labor sources say Mental Health Minister Gab Williams threw her hat in the ring but has withdrawn, with the left likely to support Mr Pallas, as factional meetings continue. Public Transport Minister Ben Carroll may still nominate for the position from the right faction.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tim Pallas appears to be ahead in race for deputy leader

children.content: This just in from state political reporter Bridget Rollason:
It's looking like Treasurer
Tim Pallas
could be Victoria's next Deputy Labor Leader.
Labor sources say Mental Health Minister
Gab Williams
threw her hat in the ring but has withdrawn, with the left likely to support Mr Pallas, as factional meetings continue.
Public Transport Minister
Ben Carroll
may still nominate for the position from the right faction.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More from state political reporter Bridget Rollason, who's down at Parliament House: Arriving at parliament, the Victorian treasurer says the outcome of the new leader is "entirely in the hands of the caucus" but hasn't ruled out a tilt at deputy. "People have been writing me off for many years now," Mr Pallas says. "I haven't made a decision about my future other than I want to serve Labor for as long as I possibly can."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tim Pallas won't rule out running for deputy leadership

children.content: More from state political reporter Bridget Rollason, who's down at Parliament House:
Arriving at parliament, the Victorian treasurer says the outcome of the new leader is "entirely in the hands of the caucus" but hasn't ruled out a tilt at deputy.

props.alt: Tim Pallas speaks to journalists outside parliament.

children.content: Treasurer Tim Pallas says he wants to continue to serve Labor.
(ABC News: Bridget Rollason)
"People have been writing me off for many years now," Mr Pallas says.
"I haven't made a decision about my future other than I want to serve Labor for as long as I possibly can."

image.altText: A woman and man in hard hats and high vis vests

props.synopsis: Deputy premier Jacinta Allan and public transport minister Ben Carroll are said to be the leading candidates for the vacated premier job.

title.children: The fight to be Victoria's next premier is likely down to just two candidates

image.altText: a barramundi held in hands with pond behind.

props.synopsis: A snap ban on commercial barramundi fishing in remote Arnhem Land waters has prompted calls for an urgent overhaul of the Northern Territory's fishing laws to better safeguard future barra stocks.

title.children: Banned barramundi fishers spotted moving into popular recreational fishing areas

image.altText: A hand holding a $100 note next to a wallet

props.synopsis: The annual rate of inflation jumped to 5.2 per cent in August, up from 4.9 per cent, on rising

title.children: Monthly inflation lifts to 5.2 per cent in August, up from 4.9 per cent, according to Bureau of Statistics

image.altText: An Indigenous man, white facial hair, with a black hat, wearing a YES shirt, looks to the media

props.synopsis: Noel Pearson, an Indigenous Australian lawyer and land rights activist, addresses the National Press Club. Follow live.

title.children: Noel Pearson says it's 'absolutely vital' for Australia to vote Yes in National Press Club speech

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mr Pearson has begun by saying it is "vital" the Voice referendum is successful. "My late friend, Bruce Tracker from the Northern Territory said, 'We're not here for wood chopping practice. We're in the main game'. "We've got two weeks and a bit to go. It's absolutely vital that we win this referendum."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Noel Pearson has begun his speech

children.content: Mr Pearson has begun by saying it is "vital" the Voice referendum is successful.
"My late friend, Bruce Tracker from the Northern Territory said, 'We're not here for wood chopping practice. We're in the main game'.
"We've got two weeks and a bit to go. It's absolutely vital that we win this referendum."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello everyone. We are back again covering the National Press Club as advocates on either side of the Voice debate make their pitches ahead of next month's referendum. Today, Yes campaigner Noel Pearson will address the National Press Club. Mr Pearson is a lawyer, land rights activist and director of the Cape York Institute for Policy and Leadership. He has been a leading Indigenous advocate in favour of the Voice to Parliament. His address will begin at 12:30pm AEST.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: National Press Club: Noel Pearson

children.content: Hello everyone.
We are back again covering the National Press Club as advocates on either side of the Voice debate make their pitches ahead of next month's referendum.
Today, Yes campaigner Noel Pearson will address the National Press Club.
Mr Pearson is a lawyer, land rights activist and director of the
Cape York Institute for Policy and Leadership.
He has been a leading Indigenous advocate in favour of the Voice to Parliament.
His address will begin at 12:30pm AEST.

image.altText: Two young people walk through a train station wearing face masks.

props.synopsis: COVID-19 has become one of Australia's leading causes of death, data from the Bureau of Statistics shows, however heart disease remains the biggest killer of Australians.

title.children: COVID enters Australia's list of leading causes of deaths for first time

image.altText: A man with a weathered face stands on a concrete pass looking over a creek on a sunny green acre lined with trees.

props.synopsis: Despite having little to do with the Voice, the blowing up of ancient rock shelters and a bungled attempt to preserve Aboriginal heritage are the issues shaping the referendum debate in WA.

title.children: How this banal concrete driveway became emblematic of WA's unique debate on the Voice

image.altText: A close-up of a corporate pwc logo on a reflective glass building panel.

props.synopsis: The annual rate of inflation picked up in August to 5.2 per cent from 4.9 per cent, according to the latest monthly measure of inflation, with housing, transport, food and insurance the most significant drivers of these increases.

title.children: Inflation jumps again in Australia, while inquiry into consulting hears 'contempt from PwC continues'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: KPMG Australia CEO Andrew Yates has acknowledged the firm's failure to report partners implicated in the exam cheating scandal in 2019. Mr Yates revealed that KPMG worked with individuals to self-report any ethical breaches, but the process was not perfect. He agreed that there is no consistent framework or standard definitions of what constitutes inappropriate behavior. He was asked to think about a system for reporting ethical breaches, and he suggested a consultancy whistleblower that can go outside the organization. Mr Yates mentioned that KPMG has a continual listening program to understand how people feel about speaking up and he emphasised the importance of having a mechanism in place for people to report ethical breaches confidentiality and anonymously.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: KPMG CEO talks about ethics and speaking up culture

children.content: KPMG Australia CEO
Andrew Yates has acknowledged the firm's failure to report partners implicated in the exam cheating scandal in 2019.
Mr Yates revealed that KPMG worked with individuals to self-report any ethical breaches, but the process was not perfect.
He agreed that there is no consistent framework or standard definitions of what constitutes inappropriate behavior.
He was asked to think about a system for reporting ethical breaches, and he suggested a consultancy whistleblower that can go outside the organization.

Mr Yates mentioned that KPMG has a continual listening program to understand how people feel about speaking up and he emphasised the importance of having a mechanism in place for people to report ethical breaches confidentiality and anonymously.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The annual rate of inflation picked up in August to 5.2 per cent from 4.9 per cent, according to the latest monthly measure of inflation. The Australian Bureau of Statistics says housing, transport, food, and insurance were the most significant drivers of the price increases. Economists were expecting inflation to increase, so they weren't taken by surprise. It's the first time monthly inflation has picked up since April. However, monthly inflation is still sitting well below its peak of 8.4 per cent in December.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Inflation is up again in Australia

children.content: The annual rate of inflation picked up in August to 5.2 per cent from 4.9 per cent, according to the latest monthly measure of inflation.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics says housing, transport, food, and insurance were the most significant drivers of the price increases.
Economists were expecting inflation to increase, so they weren't taken by surprise. It's the first time monthly inflation has picked up since April.
However, monthly inflation is still sitting well below its peak of 8.4 per cent in December.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
The Senate committee has discussed the new procurement clauses that have been put in place. Procurement is the expenditure of public money to obtain goods or services for government 
or third-party use. It enables Commonwealth entities to acquire the goods and services 
needed to deliver the government's policies, programs and services. Government 
procurement achieves value for money through competitive, open, transparent, efficient, 
ethical and publicly accountable processes. But the committee is concerned about the effectiveness of the new procurement laws and whether they have been activated. The Department of Finance said it will continue to review the Commonwealth Procurement Framework and its program 
of activities, particularly through the work of the Future Made in Australia Office, to ensure that the Commonwealth 
Procurement Framework continues to support the delivery of value for money outcomes for 
the Commonwealth.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senate Committee questions the effectiveness of the new procurement laws

children.content: The Senate committee has discussed the new procurement clauses that have been put in place.

Procurement is the expenditure of public money to obtain goods or services for government 
or third-party use.

It enables Commonwealth entities to acquire the goods and services 
needed to deliver the government's policies, programs and services.

Government 
procurement achieves value for money through competitive, open, transparent, efficient, 
ethical and publicly accountable processes.
But the committee is concerned about the effectiveness of the new procurement laws and whether they have been activated.

The Department of Finance said it will continue to review the Commonwealth Procurement Framework and its program 
of activities, particularly through the work of the Future Made in Australia Office, to ensure that the Commonwealth 
Procurement Framework continues to support the delivery of value for money outcomes for 
the Commonwealth.

image.altText: Matt Raos during the inquiry sitting in front of a little microphone.

props.synopsis: Qatar Airways says the strip search was currently before the Federal Court so could not comment extensively but provided "assurance" that the incident was a "one off".

title.children: Qatar Airways says invasive strip search of female passengers was a 'one off'

image.altText: A man and woman each holding a small child, with a crowd of people behind them

props.synopsis: The South Australian government is running a campaign encouraging consumers to "do their homework" before signing with a builder. But buyers caught up in the aftermath of multiple building companies collapsing say they did everything they could.

title.children: 'We thought we had done everything': Consumer protection in spotlight after building company collapses

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a black jumper looks at the camera with a neutral expression

props.synopsis: A speech pathologist says Irabina Autism Services in Melbourne was running controversial practices as late as February last year.

title.children: Anica has seen a lot in her job, but this experience left her 'physically shaking'

image.altText: A sign for the Launceston General Hospital and the Ashley Youth Detention Centre behind an obscured man.

props.synopsis: It was described as a landmark report into how Tasmanian authorities handled allegations of child sexual abuse in hospitals, schools, detention and out-of-home care. So what did it say?

title.children: 'We continue to be worried': The key takeaways from Tasmania's landmark abuse report

image.altText: Signs outside two service stations indicate record-breaking hikes in fuel prices

props.synopsis: The cost of petrol across Brisbane hits a new record high, with prices not expected to fall anytime soon.

title.children: Motorists urged to fuel up now as Brisbane petrol prices break new records

image.altText: Daniel Andrews.

props.synopsis: Victoria's longest-serving – and Australia's highest-paid — premier is just hours from stepping down after more than 3,200 days leading the state. Here are the hits and misses of Daniel Andrews.

title.children: Daniel Andrews steps down as an undefeated leader. What were his legacies?

image.altText: A fire at an industrial site at night.

props.synopsis: Witnesses have reported loud bangs, "multicoloured" flames and a plastic smell after a Tesla battery caught fire at one of Queensland’s first large-scale renewable energy storage sites.

title.children: Residents worry about toxic smoke as Tesla battery burns at major Qld renewable energy storage site

image.altText: Silhouettes of a four people with disability against a teal background

props.synopsis: The disability royal commission is wrapping up after four-and-a-half years. Here's how we got here and what comes next.

title.children: The disability royal commission is set to report this week. Here's a recap of the past four years

image.altText: an aerial shot of three beachfront highrise towers on the Gold Coast

props.synopsis: The Jewel's eye-catching towers are the sparkling gem in the Surfers Paradise skyline, but three years after they were built, hundreds of luxury apartments remain empty and most are not up for sale.

title.children: The curious case of the Jewel and the Gold Coast's near-empty $1.5b towers

image.altText: Trump grimaces as he speaks at a rally outside in the hot sun, with sweat visible on his face.

props.synopsis: A judge rules that Donald Trump committed fraud for years while building the real estate empire that catapulted him to fame and the White House.

title.children: Donald Trump defrauded banks for years, New York civil case rules

image.altText: A man in an orange emergency uniform picks up a brick on the top of a pile of rubble.

props.synopsis: More than 100 people are dead and 150 injured in a fire at a wedding celebration in the district of Hamdaniya in Iraq's Nineveh province, Iraqi state media reports.

title.children: More than 100 killed, 150 injured in fire at Iraq wedding party

image.altText: Picketers hold signs saying writers guild of america on strike in front of paramount pictures gate

props.synopsis: Leaders of the screenwriters' union say their nearly five-month strike will finish, bringing Hollywood partly back from a historic halt in production.

title.children: Hollywood writers strike to end after guild leaders approve deal with studios

image.altText: Anthony Rota delivers a speech from the speaker's chair in Canada's parliament.

props.synopsis: The speaker of Canada's House of Commons resigns after inviting a man who fought for a Nazi military unit during World War II to parliament to attend a speech by Ukraine's president.

title.children: Canada's speaker quits after man who fought for Nazis received standing ovation in parliament

image.altText: Australia's parliament house on a clear sunny day with tick and cross checkboxes illustrated over the top.

props.synopsis: Despite being on the cusp of early voting for the Voice to Parliament referendum, many still have questions about the proposal, one of them being; why can't it just be legislated?

title.children: You Ask We Answer: Why has the government opted for a referendum on the Voice to Parliament rather than legislation?

image.altText: Two women, one in her 30s and another in her 70s, smiling while on a stage under lights

props.synopsis: Zoleka Mandela's life was tangled with tragedy, addiction and redemption, ultimately becoming a champion for those living with cancer and people who had lost children.

title.children: Zoleka Mandela, granddaughter of Nelson Mandela, dies aged 43

image.altText: People walking outside the British Museum in London at daytime

props.synopsis: The British Museum launches a public hotline asking for help to locate some 2,000 missing artefacts, revealing they were mostly ancient Greek and Roman gems and jewellery.

title.children: British Museum seeks help to recover missing and stolen treasures

image.altText: Paul Burnham wearing Australia jacket

props.synopsis: The distinctive jacket worn by Bob Hawke when he celebrated Australia's upset win of the America's Cup in 1983 was, in fact, designed by a 23-year-old architecture student to parody nationalistic fervour.

title.children: Designer reveals the irony stitched into 'silly' Australia jacket made famous by Bob Hawke in 1983

image.altText: a composite picture of a rural landscape overlaid with a map of the NSW coast, with a inset picture of a 10-storey high house

props.synopsis: With home gym, rooftop spa, indoor swimming pool and whole-floor tennis court, this 10-storey, single family residence would look at home among the apartment towers of the Gold Coast.

title.children: Is this Australia's tallest house? This 10-storey rural monolith comes with a suspended observation deck

image.altText: Biden shouts into a megaphone.

props.synopsis: Joe Biden becomes the first sitting US president to join a picket line by striking with car workers in Michigan, and backing their call for a 40 per cent pay raise.

title.children: Joe Biden urges striking car workers to 'stick with it' in picket line visit unparalleled in history

image.altText: A footballer looks dejected after a loss.

props.synopsis: Insult is added to injury for the struggling Wallabies, as Argentina jumps the Australians in the rugby world rankings.

title.children: Wallabies hit historic low in world rankings as South Americans leapfrog struggling Australians

image.altText: Humorous sign with writing on it advertising a pub.

props.synopsis: The century-old Urandangi Hotel is being demolished, leaving the community with nowhere to buy meals, fuel or groceries for hundreds of kilometres.

title.children: Outback town left with 'nothing' after record floods force pub's demolition

image.altText: Emmanuel Macron stands behind a door frowning in the distance.

props.synopsis: Emmanuel Macron defied expectations in 2017 when he won the French presidency. Many say his self-belief was essential to his victory but it could also risk his global legacy.

title.children: Arrogance, charisma and 'the right path': The gift and the price of Emmanuel Macron's personality

image.altText: An Australian Kelpie and a woman wearing a red top.

props.synopsis: Violet the dog was vomiting, urinating, and struggling to breathe while suffering a violent high from eating marijuana that had been left at a Brisbane park.

title.children: Violet the kelpie nearly died from a violent high after eating marijuana at a dog park

image.altText: An older gentlalnd with grey hair and glasses stands in front of dozens of freshly ironed and covered clohtes on coathangers

props.synopsis: After running his family's Tamworth-based dry cleaners for 61 years, Ross says there is one stain he certainly won't miss.

title.children: Dry cleaning family to hang up the iron after 82 years of 'mud, blood and beer'
